Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 11:18AM cmbear wrote: Agree with SpecialK, bright red is a much better thing to have. Scary to see, but no need to bother a doc unless it happens repeatedly and is more than just a wipe. You might want to take some stool softeners like Collace to make it easier on your poor colon. And stay away from chocolate and spicy foods for awhile. And don't worry about the time delay. Polyps are the SLOWEST growing thing in your body.
Posts.Title: Colonoscopy... wallycat wallycat

Posts.Content: May 16, 2011 04:42PM cmbear wrote: I had the same issue. Asked my MO when I first started chemo and she said stage III because of my tumor size--same as you--never got a precise measurement for my tumor. (also one palpable node) A lot of it has do with WHY the gave you neo adjuvant therapy. For me, my tumor was so large they couldn't operate until they shrunk it down some. Fortunately, for me too, the chemo melted it all away. What was the reasoning for your neo-therapy? There are several websites that will give you probabilities, but each person has SOOO many different variables that effect their future that it is really all a crapshoot. I have been told anywhere from 60 to 80 to 89% chance of survival. I worried about it for a long time and then I eventually gave up on that. All I can do is  what I can to prevent it from coming back, and not stress about it.
Posts.Title: neoadjuvant chemotherapy and staging ReadingMama Shari0707

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 09:49AM cmbear wrote: My MO would not give the go ahead until I was a year out from chemo. My BS would have done anything I wanted. They are just being precautions with stage III's in case of reoccurrence. She really wanted me to keep it in indefinitely. Uh,no! Nope, didn't want that reminder hanging out on my chest. NOW, in hind site, I have found that blood draws are a pain in the you know what because all the veins in my non-affected arm are blown. Should I have kept it in for every six month exam, or MRI's with contrast? Maybe. Or maybe the nurses have to be a little more skilled to get blood from me. Btw, I have my port in a little specimen jar in a drawer. Kind of creepy, I know but it's my own personal reminder that I am moving on past this whole mess.
Posts.Title: PORT REMOVAL many MiniMacsMom

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 11:39PM cmbear wrote: I agree with all the above, Biotene and warm water salt rinses help heal. Find a toothpaste that doesn't have sodium lauryl sulphate--Sensodyne has one. SLD tends to irritate mouth sores possibly even cause them. I have been using it for awhile and it has really helped reduce the amount of sores in my mouth. If you are really miserable, your doc can prescribe Magic Mouthwash. It totally deadens your whole mouth, but if you are in severe pain, it might be what helps. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2011 10:29PM cmbear wrote: Don't feel like you have to be wonder woman! You just had major surgery!! With a BMX, all kinds of nerves are damaged so your pain may change over time.Plus you will have some swelling for awhile yet.  It does eventually get better but take it easy for awhile. Too much pushing before your body is ready may cause you to take a little longer to heal. It does get better tho--mine was Jan 18,  and its beginning to fade a little in my memory bank!! But once you get your drains out, you'll feel a whole lot different. Sending you big but gentle ((((HUGS))))))
Posts.Title: My Chest Aches Michele_T ibcmets

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 10:16AM cmbear wrote: Amyjo, sending you positive thoughts. Don't feel bad about crying, it helps let the stress out. And you can always come on here and we will send you big hugs!!   Congrats Blindsided for moving on to the next stage of healing!! You must feel wonderful. Duckyb1, I pass by the bell at my center everyday, and everyday I think "one more day closer to ringing the darn bell." I cried like a baby when I rang my chemo bell, all the nurses came out from the treatment rooms and cheer and hug you. It is a great feeling. Can't wait to ring this bell, for me it'll be almost a year of treatments and surgeries I will be glad to have BEHIND me!!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2011 09:28AM cmbear wrote: Sharon, I love the paper chain gift, what a great friend! You are lucky. I get the whole "tired of this cancer thing."  I have that breakdown before I have to go to work too often I am afraid! Can't find a shirt that doesn't rub on the burn, that doesn't show my rads burn and all my rads' techs lovely artwork. Unfortunately, my boss is not so understanding. I used all my vacation and sick time during chemo, took 4 weeks of short term disability for my DBMX, and now I have no "time" to take off. So if I feel crappy, sore, ON FIRE---I go to work. I work retail, and her concern is all about the store and sales. To say she is not a people person is an understatement. Fortunately, the rest of the store is very supportive. If I didn't have a son in college, I would quit in a nanosecond, but my husband thinks I "need" to work. (well, we do for the $$) RRggh, enough about my ranting!! Ducky, I love the comment about the "big girl's panties!" Sometimes I don't want to be strong, sometimes I just want to melt into the pity party, but I know I am my best supporter. I have to tell myself to stop crying and think of the anything BUT cancer. This is only a year of my life and I WILL not let it have more. There is so much more to me, to ALL of us than BC. We are vibrant, loving, beautiful, and loved women who happen to share an illness that will not take our souls. If we can get thru the physical aspects--with a little help from meds and great friends--and the mental aspects--with the support of all you lovely ladies-- we will all be stronger for it. And as for being a survivor. . . I'll personally claim it when I done with treatment and they tell me with no uncertainty that I am cancer free. But I am definitely a chemo survivor, and can't wait to be a rads survivor!!!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: May 23, 2012 11:46PM cmbear wrote: I had neo-adjuvant chemo too,  starting off with 12x Taxol. My hair fell out about the second week too. It helps to cut it real short before you start chemo so you don't see big clumps of hair fall out. Its not as painful when you hair is shorter --remember the first morning I found it on my pillowcase. Time to shave!! I had a port, it was never not considered between 2 rounds of chemo and all the blood draws. It does depend on how many chemo tx you will have. Glad I had it, of course even happier when it came out! I had nueropathy fairly bad in my feet, didn't lose my nails but they did look pretty awful for awhile. Amazing what a little nail polish will cover up! Tree tea oil helps. I had mouth issues, sores, lack of taste. Your MO can prescribe Magic Mouthwash to help with that. I worked all thru Taxol, only taking off the day of chemo. After that, I had 4X AC. The worst SE effect was the horrible joint pain. Hard to get in and out of a chair. I was working retail and on my feet all day. Totally wiped out at the end of the day.  My hair actually started to grow back then--wispy sad little things. I wore a wig to work because I just didn't want the hassle of talking about it. But at home, it was baseball hats and a scarf here and there. It's all what you are comfortable with. I live in Florida and darn if those wigs don't get itchy in the heat. My first haircut was a few months after chemo, just cause it was a little straggly. I'm now a 1 1/2 years out and I've lost track of how many times I've gotten it cut--and its past my shoulders. It does come back!!  My biggest surprise about chemo was the actual experience was not painful or awful at all. I brought a bag with all kinds of things to read, listen to, etc. I usually yakked the whole time with my MIL (my chemo partner) or slept. I slept ALOT!! They also give you all kinds of drugs to help you thru chemo.  Can't say it was enjoyable, but it wasn't as bad as I had feared.  Good luck with your TX. What kind of chemo will you be having?
Posts.Title: Chemo advice from veterans? Please post!!!! ElleBee pamelahope

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2011 04:54PM cmbear wrote: Hi Ladies, joining your group as late as I possibly can!! Can't believe its almost March, 9 weeeks from my last chemo, 5 weeks from my BMX. My first rads treatment was Feb 23, so 4 down, 29 to go!!! So far so good. I did have to delay starting tx since I couldn't get my arm over my head. It is still pretty darn sore under my lymph (removed) side even tho I keep exercising like a mad woman. I haven't done any "real" exercises, I am just too pooped all the time. That and my joints hurt.  I have been creaming it up, my doc suggested Natrabio's candula cream, but after listening to all you lovely ladies I may splurge on some miaderm. I am deathly afraid of burning since I am still very numb, don't think I would feel the start of a burn. Consequently, i find myself staring at my chest a lot to make sure it hasn't turned pink. I know its early, but I am just a tad worried!!  Tomorrow I get to see my cutie RO for my weekly appt, hopefully he will tell me all is going swimmingly!!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 06:09AM - edited Apr 8, 2011 06:09AM by cmbear Tori, I am so sorry to hear about the Shingles. What a crappy thing to happen. Use your meds faithfully and find extra special time to relax and take your mind off of what you're going through. Stress can do a number on you right now. Think of being on a nice quiet beach, under a cabana of course, being served a beautiful fruity island beverage by some hunky cabana boy. The sound of the waves gently rolling in, steel drums playing in the background. . .  I'd be there in heartbeat if I could!!!

MO wants me to wait for at least a year after ending TX--which puts me at April 2012. Anyway--I am so happy for you!!!
Posts.Title: Marking 8 years since... Trish03 CherylinOhio

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2011 08:11AM cmbear wrote: Just so glad to be on the other side of this phase. It's been almost a week and my skin has changed to a weird brown color, except for where the boost area--which is still quite red and raw. I tried about what ever lotion I could get my hands on. Went thru 2 tubes of calendula cream, on my second of miaderm, hydricortisone, and last week I bought some Aquafor. Fancy name for vaseline--but it really, really helped with the peeling and dryness. I layer the lotions and then wear an extra large cotton tee under my regular shirt. I am surprised at how it was so raw and now looks so brown in about a weeks time. But most of all, I am just glad its almost--almost gone. You ladies sound like you have great support systems--children can be such a blessing. Ihave 2 teenage boys and where as I get my share of hugs, they are totally uncomfortable with what I am going thru.But I do have 2 great sisters, one who is a 3 year BC survivor herself. Yesterday, she sent me a fantastic box of chocolates to help celebrate another phase being done. ---the kind of chocolate that you nibble and not share with the kids!! : ) Hugs to all of my wonderful rads friends, it has been a such a help having your advice, friendship and gentle hugs!!!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2010 11:27PM cmbear wrote: Hi everyone, Not sure of my surgery date, but my onc says it should be mid-January. I meet with my BS next week to nail down the date. I still have one last AC treatment next Wednesday, three days before Christmas. I am the last one on my July chemo thread, everyone else has moved on to rads or finished treatment all together, makes me feel kinda like the last kid picked for kickball. I know nothing about what to expect, except that my onc says reconstruction is at least 18 months down the road for me. Wants me to get thru rads and heal completely from surgery, chemo,rads,etc,etc. Part of me wants this all to be over with, not sure I want to have to revisit this whole thing in 18 months. I am very grateful that I have someplace new to call home. Thanks Ladies for being here and listening. Claire

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 09:46AM cmbear wrote: Good morning ladies! Been home for a few days and so far so good. Pain is tolerable, just comes in sharp spasms totally unannounced, not constant. In fact the wound site is still numb. Is that normal? Slept one night in the recliner, last night on the pullout couch. Both had their advantages, but tonight will be on the couch again. The rough part was watching my DH empty my drains and then pull off my bandages. He kept reassuring me that this was temporary and it would all be better soon. Needless to say, he took it better than me. The look in his eyes is hard to take. I know he loves me dearly, but he is scared and doesn't want me to see that. I hate that he has to go thru this. But I am fortunate to have him.  Haven't gotten the path report back, but since the neo chemo shrunk the tumor so much, I am expecting nothing but positive news. And on the fun side, still waiting for the colace to kick in.. . .any time now!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 10:14AM cmbear wrote: Redsky--Take care of yourself, and hope the next few days fly by! Fuzzylemon, welcome and please feel at home here. We all have different stories, but are all traveling the same road. We are here for each other!! Sonnet--one thing you will learn on this site is that mammos are not fool proof. None of my mammos showed my 8 cm ILC tumor. It's easy to get frustrated by the inaccuracies of the screening process. The good news is you had no node involvement, that is awesome!!! Cindy ME-good luck with chemo today. What are you scheduled for? I took everything but the kitchen sink when I first started chemo. Ended up only bringing my own pillow, blanket and my ereader, even though I hardly ever had time to read anything. Either I was too busy yakking with my chemo partner or sleeping. Do not be afraid of your anti-nausea meds, they will become your friends. You can do this!! BTW, I fell asleep on my side last night. WOO-HOO! But woke up at 4 and could not get comfortable. Ended up on the recliner. Someday I will get this sleep thing down!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 08:19AM cmbear wrote: Alice--I am so sorry to hear of your struggles. Hope the rest of your recovery is less stressful.  Cindy--Glad to hear that your chemo went well. Keep up your strength. Don't  overdo it, chemo can be sneaky and side effects, for some people, can be cummulative. By the end of my 6 months, i was pretty wiped out. My iron levels tanked and even tho I have been taking supplements, by onc called yesterday and wants to do a rbc transfusion.  Oh boy! Also met with my radiologist to set up my radiation. He was not too happy that I was not as bendable as I should be. Can't get my LND arm over my head. Owww. Best to do double duty on those arm exercises!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 10:09AM cmbear wrote: Laurie--Happy early birthday!!! do something special just for you. Celebrate another year and being on the road to recovery. You deserve some celebration time!!!! Sue, don't know about the leaking part, seems like they shouldn't. My drain sites leaked for several days after they removed the drains, but 2 weeks out, I would call your BS. Yesterday, I removed my last steristrip. Now I feel truly naked. But it did take some of the discomfort away. I have heard mixed reports about the numbness. Some of it goes away but it stays numb around the surgery site. My numbness on my cancer side goes up my chest to my shoulder blade and under my arm. It feels like I have an elastic band around my armpit--by the end of the day it is quite painful. That is if "numbness" can be painful.   dmho--glad the drain issue was resolved. One down, two to go! Sending good  thoughts that your skin is healing, slowly, but healing!! Gentle Hugs!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2011 10:34AM cmbear wrote: Alice, my chest was tight too until I got a little more consistent with my stretches. I have only done PT 3 times and she also told me to keep up with the strectches and massages. My chest is getting pretty raw from rads (19 of 33) so she told me to keep the exercizes to a minimum on that side till I am done with rads.   Congrats with the new found head freedom!! I stopped wearing my scarves and hats about 2 weeks ago. Just beginning to get too hot down here in Orlando. Plus it was beginning to fill in enough that I was more comfortable to be seen "naked." I laugh everytime someone says that I have a nice shaped head!!  Of course, I do have a friend that keeps asking me when I am going to start coloring it--I don't think she realized how naturally gray I was since I had been coloring for so many years!!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 11:57AM cmbear wrote: YEAHHHH!!! BIG HAPPY DANCE!!!!  Just came back from BS with path report in hand. Clean margins and no sign of tumor thanks to neo-adjuvant  chemo. Such a relief to see it in writing. Out of 12 nodes only one not involved, 4 with micrometstatis, so 7/12. Phewwww!! Never knew the node involvement before because to the neo-ad chemo so it was a relief just to know. But the other great thing is that I went in cause my right drain was leaking. He looked at my output and asked if I wanted them out. Don't think I could say yes fast enough!!! i can actually put my arms down. Can't wait to sleep tonight!!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 09:46AM cmbear wrote: Jorja, you don't have to apologize here. Cancer is cancer, whether you have a 1 cm or 8 cm tumor. You still feel violated and wounded no matter what stage you are. After 7 months of dealing with this, I have learned that we all have different paths, different ways of dealing with our fear, our loss, our challenges. But we all celebrate together our triumphs and wins against this nasty battle we all are fighting.  Chemo is very doable. You feel crappy for awhile but time passes and you realize that all those nasty chemicals in your body are killing all that nasty cancer. I'll do what I have to do to make sure I don't have to go thru this again. As my sister, who is a 2 year BC survivor, said, you feel crappy for about a year and then you move on. Make the rest of your life about being well and not being sick. Terri, I am sorry about the drug problems. I take my pain killers at night--mostly out of fear of rolling over and being in serious pain. So far, it has worked, I wake up in the same position I fell asleep in. I am so happy to get 6 hours of uninterupted sleep, I could just spit!! Yesterday i went to the mall with my MIL and went to one store. By the time I got home, I was throbbing and exhausted, afraid I had over did it. Guess baby steps for me. Hope everyone is resting and moving as best they can. We will get thru this!!!! Dmho, Barbara and Redskyatnight, enjoy this weekend!! Do something real fun, let yourself relax and know we are here for you!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 07:57AM cmbear wrote: dmho-my drain did the same thing from the even at the hospital. My husband taped it back towards my back, parallel to my ribs and that seemed to help. He put gauze between me and the tube and then on top of the tube and taped it down. My Bs office couldn't get my in for a day so when I saw him on Tuesday(wed surgery) he went ahead and pulled them because my output was low. Do you think you may have pulled the tube out? You should still be able to feel it under your skin. Keep an eye on your drain "holes" and make sure they don't look infected. And don't be afraid to call again this weekend if your temp stays consistent. That is what the doc is there for!!! Hope you feel better this weekend and don't let it stress you. Sending good thoughts your way!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 07:10AM cmbear wrote: So good to hear you all are doing as well as you are. Brave little soldiers!!  We had a recliner that was in dire need of being replaced so we bought a new one last week. I have dubbed it my recovery chair, and I am sure after this is all said and done, I will not want to sit in it. The old one was actually my husband's "Archie" chair, so this new one will have a whole new set of memories. Great idea about asking around for a wedge pillow--will start asking today!! On a totally different note, does anyone out there run low temps? I am lucky if I break 97.3 and I am always freezing. I guess its normal, but it is real annoying when you are trying to determine if you are running a fever. What is normal? What is a fever?
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 07:19AM cmbear wrote: Alice--what a great idea about the leaking--using a sanitary pad. LOL. Mine leaked at the hospital and every other day at home(my right propholatic side, I do not have reconstruction on either side-yet) Last night my DH taped my line parallel to my ribs and surgical seam. So far no leak. When it bends straight down or gets lose, it leaks. I am going in this a.m. to have doc look at it, two days earlier than my scheduled one week out appt. It probably means my drains might stay in longer, ickk, but at least I'll get  peace of mind that there is nothing wrong. What bothered me yesterday was when listening about Congressman Giffords brain drain, the medical reporter said that if a drain leaks out, that means that if something can get out, something can get in(bacteria). Definitely don't want that!! Vikki, I had Nuerontin for neuropathy in my feet and hands during Taxol treatment. I had 11 weeks of Taxol--suppose to have had 12. My doc was concerned about my neuropathy and thought the Taxol had done what it needed to do in the 11 treatments, so she ended it early. Itook the neurontin until the worst part of my neuropathy stopped. Doc didn't want me to be on the drug for extended time due to side effects. I never noticed any effects except chemo brain--which is hard to pin down the exact cause.Absolutely the WORST side effect I had of chemo.  And again to all the women going in this week, stay strong, and see you on the other side!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 05:09PM cmbear wrote: Sue, don't feel bad about sleeping and taking it easy--you just had major surgery!! Remember, in the old days, we all would have been in the hospital for 5-7 days. Your body will tell you when its ready to heal.  I still can't sleep on my sides, which means that my back is still angry at me for making me sleep on it for the last 2 weeks. It only hurts when I am laying down, not when I am sitting or standing of moving around. RRGGHH!!! I was sleeping on the foldout couch and my DH got all sad on me that he missed me in bed. So Saturday, I went back to our bed and I haven't slept since. Never thought I would miss the couch!! I think I have convinced myself that I will roll over that I just keep waking myself up. Amazing how the mind messes with you even while you are sleeping.   Go in on Wednesday to have check up with onc and Radiologist to set up rads. Step 3 in my healing process. Seems downhill from here! Hope all the ladies today had smooth sailing. Pheww, January is over. WE MADE IT!!!!!!!! On to recovery!!!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 08:04AM cmbear wrote: Ooh forgot to ask. Does anyone have cording? Guess I haven't been doing enough exercizing (OK, I admit I was afraid to move my left arm for awhile) so now I am paying for it. My arm hurts from about half way to my elbow to my armpit. Very tender and sore. I am trying to be aggressive with my exercizes but it hurts. Wah, wah, wah.  And on another note, has anyone gone back to work? How long is everyone taking off? My boss is not the understanding type and pressuring me to come back before I feel ready and my family is ticked at me that I gave in to her. Advice please!!!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2011 11:57AM cmbear wrote: Wow, this experience has taken us all down different roads!! For those struggling with infection and pain, I'm sending big gentle hugs. What a roller coaster to be on, and I am sorry y'all have had to go this extra pain.  I haven't posted for awhile but I still read daily. Guess I have been feeling out of it,since my docs didn't want to do recon for awhile. I am feeling kind of down listening to all of you returning to being  closer to a "normal" look. I look at my concave chest, and there are days I feel deformed and wonder if I will ever accept this "new" me.  Phlllllattt!!  Pity party!! Started rads last week, and it is incredibly easy process although you have to leave your pride and modesty at the door. Just wondering why all my male docs and nurses have to be so good looking?? : ) Makes the day quite interesting!! Hope everyone has a fantastic week, do something fun just for yourself!! I am going this afternoon to get my first post chemo hair cut. It's not long but there are some stragglers that make me feel like a crazy woman. Yesterday I absent mindedly stepped out of the house w/o a hat or scarf and felt horribly self conscience. Not there yet. Soon I hope!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 11:46AM cmbear wrote: OOh, and I itch too, but I attribute that to the skin healing from the rads. I see my MO in 3 weeks so I will talk to her. It's probably more annoying than anything. And I don't have an appt with my surgeon because I am on the "wait 9-12 months before recon" program.  Guess I need to be more consistent with my stretches!

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 09:05AM cmbear wrote: Hope the best today for Alice and Gutsy. May the angels be looking over you today! Be waiting to hear from you on the other side!!! Jackie--I am so, so sorry for your postponement, get yourself healthy!!! My DH has been home sick with a nasty cold for the last 2 days and I have been Lysoling like a mad woman. I work retail and almost everyone I look at is a drooling, sniveling pile of sneezing mucus spreaders. I wish I could lock myself in a room until Jan 19!!!! Darn this cold and flu season!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 08:01AM cmbear wrote: Sounds very similar to how my BC started. Painful, swollen, heavy and eventually very hard. Didn't show on mammo as anything but dense breast. Finally got my gyn to refer me to SOMEBODY to look at it. I saw the BS, he looked at it and said yup, very suspicious. He did an US biopsy that morning. Didn't see a radiologist till I started chemo. I would skip the consult and find a doc that will do the biopsy, surgeon or rad doc. Seems like an extra step that is not totally needed. Unless you want to use it as second opinion.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Confused about my upcoming BS appointment pp729 Sommer43

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 07:02AM cmbear wrote: My date is on the calendar too for January 19th 7 am. Decided on the BMX ( half fear of the unknown and half vanity of not being one sided) Totally selfish but what the heck. Bs surgeon is wary of IBC even Onc not concerned. Never did biopsy for that,  just the ilc, even though that is what he initially thought I had that.(red, orange peeled skin). So now I am a little freaked that he is tacking on another issue late in the game--just a little confused. He said pathology report after BMX will give us all the answers. And since I had such a good response to neo-advajunct chemo that I shouldn't be concerned. Easy for him to say.  I don't have a gym for the next few weeks, any one have any suggestions for at home exercises besides sit-ups? I know I am suppose to get up and move but with my last AC treatment four days ago and my Neulasta 3 days ago, I am still moving like a snail. I need some motivation!!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 12:31AM cmbear wrote: kwhitmo-CONGRATS!!! You must be so happy!!! I had my last treatment last Wednesday and I know you are doing a happy dance right now!! What a wonderful feeling!! Sorry to hear you have to have the MX after the first surgery, that is not  right in so many ways. My surgery is the week before yours and I am plenty nervous too. Terri-I would be having a little hissy fit if I were you. I hope it all works out for you, I know having that family support there is a very essential part of recovery. Got my fingers crossed for you. And thanks for all the exercise advice, now that it is thawing outside, I may start my walking again. Living in Florida we do get spoiled for our warm weather!!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 01:04PM cmbear wrote: Alice--You must be over the moon! What wonderful news!! I am hoping for the same results after my 6 months of chemo. I kinda would like to think that it was worth something, and your case,it was the best of all worlds. Thanks for the positive thoughts, and I will try to keep up my attitude going into next week. Laurie and Gutsy--Glad to see you are handling recovery so well. Gutsy your loopy note made me laugh--it is all too real, isn't it?!!  Day by day, you are all an inspiration. BTW, a co-worker was just diagnosed this week with BC. I am heartbroken cuz she has been a true friend to me during the last many months. And she just had back surgery before the holidays. It's just not right, too many of us out there.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 08:33AM cmbear wrote: Gutsy--OH my, I get exactly what you are saying about the last 6 months! I have been going to work when my brain was only functioning at minimal capacity. I wanted to show that things hadn't changed and that I was still capable of doing everything that I could before. My life has changed and will be changed for the rest of my life. I don't want to wallow in it but sometimes I want to quit it all and run away. I'm tired of thinking about BC, worrying about it, talking about it. Like you, I am drained. I want time to have a rebirth, to start over and feel whole again.  Good luck today to GW, Min and Maria, just let go and yourself be taken care of.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 10:42AM cmbear wrote: Alice when do you start rads? I go in Friday for mapping, and will go forward if I can get my left arm to co-operate with the whole over the head moment. Being very stubborn. Guess I started my exercises too late.  Sue and Renee, great news!!! What a relief for you!! Now on to healing!!! Cindy, Cindala and Joan, I have that same pain in my back, guess its got to be related to the surgery. Will be great to know what causes it! I get the whole scar and not wanting to see it. I am having phantom pain, want to scratch whats not there. About half of my steri strips have come off(with a little help) but not ready to see the whole scar bare and naked. I guess I am in that stage of grief--denial. Sometimes I just want to cry and and fast forward a year. I want the moment when BC is not my main focus in life.  Hope this week brings healing and strength to all.
